misconceptions.name: Implemented an average-acceleration calculator instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of a program that reads 5 integers and prints the sum of the even ones. The entire structure of the code (prompt, variable names, data types, and formula) targets a different physics problem than the one specified in the question.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that asks for v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integer values from the user (e.g., using nextInt in a loop), check for each whether it is even using n % 2 == 0, keep a running sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum as in the sample run.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers.
The program reads three doubles using nextDouble instead of five integers using nextInt.
There is no loop to process 5 inputs.
There is no conditional check using the modulus operator to test evenness.
The main computation is (v1 - v0) / t, unrelated to summing even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion of this programming task with a different physics-style exercise (average acceleration), or reusing a previous solution without adapting it to the current problem statement. The student appears not to have decomposed the required behavior from the provided prompt and sample run.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and sample run carefully. Before coding, list: (1) what inputs are required (5 integers), (2) what operation is needed (select even numbers via n % 2 == 0), (3) how many times to repeat the input/processing (loop 5 times), and (4) what output format is expected. Then rewrite the program to: declare an int sum = 0; use a loop that runs 5 times, reading an int each time; if the number is even, add it to sum; after the loop, print the sum.
related_concepts: Input parsing with Scanner (nextInt vs nextDouble)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every aspect of the program (variable names, prompt, number and type of inputs, and formula) aligns with an average-acceleration example and does not attempt any part of the required 'sum of even numbers from 5 integers' behavior.

evidence.note: The code reads three doubles for v0, v1, and t and computes average acceleration, which does not match the requirement to read 5 integers and sum only the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Problem Goal
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration (a physics formula: `(v1 - v0) / t`) which requires reading 3 floating-point numbers, completely failing to address the actual assignment requirement: reading 5 integers and summing the even numbers among them.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have solved an entirely different problem (calculating acceleration) or submitted the incorrect code for this submission slot.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires initializing a sum accumulator, using a loop to read exactly 5 integer values, and employing a conditional check (modulo 2) inside the loop to determine if the number should be added to the sum.
symptoms: Code prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Variables are declared as 'double'
The mathematical operation is based on a physics formula, not summation or modulus operations
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading or confusing the assignment prompt, leading to solving a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the prompt for Q1 carefully. Your submitted code solves for average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers. You must restart the problem focusing on counting, looping 5 times, and using the modulo operator.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code (variable names, output text, and calculation) clearly implements the average acceleration formula, a task fundamentally different from summing even numbers.

evidence.note: Reads 3 doubles by naming them v0, v1, and t, contradicting the requirement to read 5 integers.

evidence.snippet:
t = (v1 - v0) / t;
        System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + t);
evidence.note: Calculates and prints 'average acceleration', showing the student focused on a physics formula instead of summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Solving wrong problem - acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student has written code to calculate average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t, which is a completely different problem than the one assigned. The assignment asks to read 5 integers and sum only the even numbers, but the student's code reads 3 decimal values and performs a physics calculation instead.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a problem about calculating acceleration from velocity and time values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct task is to read 5 integers from the user, identify which ones are even (divisible by 2), and output their sum. For example, from [3, 8, 2, 7, 4], the even numbers are [8, 2, 4] which sum to 14.
symptoms: Program reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Program performs division to calculate acceleration instead of checking for even numbers
Output shows 'average acceleration' instead of 'sum of even numbers'
Logic completely unrelated to the assignment requirements
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either misread the assignment, copied code from a different problem, or is solving the wrong question entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. The task requires: (1) Read exactly 5 integers, (2) Check each one to see if it's even (n % 2 == 0), (3) Add up only the even ones, (4) Print the sum. Start fresh with the correct algorithm.
related_concepts: Loop structures for processing multiple inputs
Modulo operator for determining even/odd numbers
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the code solves an entirely different problem (physics acceleration) rather than the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). There is no overlap between the two problems.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t, which is the physics formula for acceleration. This has nothing to do with reading 5 integers and summing even numbers as required by Q1.
Prompts for physics variables (v0, v1, t) instead of requesting 5 integers as specified in the assignment.
Output describes 'average acceleration' rather than 'sum of even numbers' as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (different problem solved)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of a program that reads 5 integers and prints the sum of the even numbers. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the actual problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads initial velocity, final velocity, and time and then computes average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which of them are even (using n % 2 == 0), compute the sum of just those even numbers, and print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Uses double variables v0, v1, t instead of integer variables for five inputs.
No loop is present to process 5 inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0).
Output describes average acceleration rather than sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to correctly interpret or follow the written problem statement, leading to solving a different textbook-style problem instead of the specified task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement and restate it in your own words before coding. Then design the algorithm: read 5 integers (e.g., in a loop), check each with n % 2 == 0, add even ones to a running sum, and finally print the sum with the required message.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All elements of the program (inputs, variable names, calculation, and output text) correspond to an average acceleration problem, with no attempt to read 5 integers or sum even numbers.

evidence.note: The code clearly solves an average acceleration problem instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address assignment prompt
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration (a = (v1 - v0) / t) instead of solving the assigned problem, which was to read 5 integers and calculate the sum of the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or submitted code intended for a completely different assignment (possibly involving kinematics/physics) or fundamentally misunderstood the prompt requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student must write code specifically to address the prompt: reading 5 user inputs and calculating the sum of even numbers.
symptoms: Code attempts to read v0, v1, and t variables, not 5 integers.
Code calculates acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.
Code uses floating-point types (double) when integer input and sums were implied.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of problem requirements or submitting incorrect file/code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the full assignment prompt carefully and delete the current physics calculation code. Focus on using a loop structure and the modulo operator (%) to check for even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure, variable names (v0, v1, t), and calculation (`(v1 - v0) / t`) unequivocally demonstrate an attempt to solve a different problem (average acceleration) than the one assigned (sum of even numbers).

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating average acceleration with inputs v0, v1, and t, which is irrelevant to summing 5 even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Problem Misunderstanding
misconceptions.description: The student has solved an entirely different problem. Instead of writing a program to sum even numbers, the student wrote code to calculate average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t. This shows a critical misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is asking them to implement an acceleration calculation program (perhaps reading the class name 'Q1Acceleration' or confusing this with a physics problem).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers, identifying which ones are even, summing only those even integers, and printing the result. The problem is a basic conditional loop exercise, not a physics calculation.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
No loop structure present
No conditional check for even numbers
Performs arithmetic calculation instead of filtering and summing
Output is completely different from expected format
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confused the problem statement with a different assignment, possibly due to the class name 'Q1Acceleration' or working from an old/wrong assignment sheet
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: (1) read 5 integers, (2) use a loop to process each one, (3) check if each is even with 'n % 2 == 0', (4) add to a sum if even, (5) print the sum with the correct message.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code is unambiguously for a different problem (acceleration calculation). There is zero overlap between the actual assignment requirements and what was submitted.

evidence.note: Entire program solves a physics acceleration problem instead of the sum-of-even-numbers problem. Uses physics variable names (v0, v1, t) and acceleration formula, which have no relevance to the actual assignment.
Declares 3 doubles instead of 5 integers. Assignment requires reading 5 integers for filtering even numbers.
Prompts for physics variables, not 5 integers. Assignment requires input prompt 'Enter 5 integers:' or similar.
Performs acceleration calculation instead of summing even numbers. No loop, no even-number check.
